turn.text: But I think that for once -- for once a negative is a -- a positive, that if the Government would not have accepted, would not have assumed or found in the evidence sufficient basis for concluding that this fellow was a government agent, it couldn't have been indifferent to what is basic to the beginning of a defense of entrapment.

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: Well, I -- I don't know whether the United States Attorney overlooked it or what happened, Your Honor.
As I say --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well but the -- but that you say (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: -- this is -- is the first place which have (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)
-- No matter, the Government does -- a US Attorney or an Assistant Attorney or a first year law student knows entrapment means something supposedly done by government agents.
And if that -- that question isn't contested --

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: Well I --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- presumably fair.

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: The matter was brought up here, Your Honor, and I wanted to refer you to the record because I do think it is questionable.
And as I say I don't think it's been raised before but I do think its questionable.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: I don't think -- I think he wasn't.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But I do say that it isn't raisable and that's because I've --

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: All right, sir.
All right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- abstained and now say, oh, well, but there's no issue of entrapment because he wasn't a government agent.

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: Well, I'm sorry, Your Honor.
I thought that this Court was interested in that point and that's why I brought it up.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And let me -- I can assure you've been interesting.

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: Now, according to Kalchinian's testimony that while he had asked the defendant to supply the name of his party from whom he could obtain narcotics, the defendant didn't do that.
Instead, he suggested displeasure.
Now, in this respect, I -- I must confess that I read this record.
And there are two ways you could read it.
One of them you can read it to understand that as far as Kalchinian was concerned, that the defendant offered it to him.
He offered to sell it to him.

But the cross-examination of Mr. Lowenberg was based on prior testimony indicates again that -- that that is a very debatable at least, subject as to who suggested at first that Sherman sell the narcotics to -- to Kalchinian.
I -- I have trouble finding out just exactly what the fact was.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: I understand or understood (Inaudible) argument of the counsel for petitioner that there is no question about that.

That on each of the three instances of questioning, Sherman had gotten $25, $25 worth of heroin and then by arrangement met Kalchinian on the street corner and passed over what was supposed to be half of the $25 worth of heroin, asked then, Kalchinian to pay him $15, that which covered one half of the cost of heroin, plus the $2.50 taxi cab fee.
I am sure, that's quite --

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: As I understood counsel for petitioner.

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: And that's -- that's my understanding of -- of what transpired there.
But I'm talking about this prior arrangement back in August when they first made the arrangement to -- to buy narcotics.
You see, this -- this purchase on what this indictment is based was made December – December or November 1st, was the first buy.
But Kalchinian says that “I've -- I started buying for him back in the 1st of September.”
And so, the question is whether he was induced wrongfully back the 1st of September to sell narcotics to Kalchinian.
And Kalchinian says, “I asked him to supply me with a name or introduce me to somebody I could get it from and his source and instead the defendant insisted on selling it me.”
And perhaps, there was a reason.
Maybe, he wanted to make a profit.
And we -- we contend that in itself indicates some evidence of a predisposition, if the case isn't the same as the one we had here before.
Here, there are two discussions about the narcotic addict.
It isn't in -- but on the other hand, we have a man who is, admittedly, violating the law with respect to narcotics.
He is buying them.
He says I can get it.
He says I have source.
So, he isn't a man too innocent in this.

And to show whether he was a -- a person engaged in it we brought the record of his prior convictions, which was a conviction0 for a sale and a conviction for, as I believe, Mr. Lowenberg points out for a purchase.
Now, those two convictions together with the evidence here that he was a narcotic addict that's why he was going to the doctor, he was able to get the drug.
He was -- had been buying it.
He could get it when Kalchinian couldn't.
He was still dealing with narcotics in one way or another.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How do you know Kalchinian then couldn't get it?

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: Well, Kalchinian said that he couldn't that his -- and then that's in here, at record 116.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He did get it going in and through other sales, didn't he?
Two other purchases, turned it over to the Government.

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: Well, that apparently was earlier than August.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, this is June, the same year.

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: And this was June -- June or July.
He doesn't say when.
But he said, “Give me the name you know him,” and then he said, “Well he wanted to know the name of this prior dealer."
"Did you cause his arrest?”
“No.”
“Could you give me the name of that dealer?”
“No, if I don't -- I don't know if I know it -- his right name.”
“Give me the name as you know him under.”
Answer “Nick, Nick, that's all I knew him.”
“Did give you the Bureau of Narcotics his name, Nick's name?”
Answer “I did not mention it to the Narcotics Bureau.”
“Did you give them a description of this man?”
Answer “No.”
Then he asked, "Do you recall operating with the Bureau of Narcotics at that particular time?"
“Not at that particular time.”
“Not at that particular time?
Did you subsequently -- when you started to cooperate then, were you still getting narcotics from Nick?”
“Whom were you getting it from then?”
Answer “I was not getting it from anyone.”
“You mean you were up at the doctor's office for a cure?”
“That is right.”
“And you did not have a cravings for narcotics while you were undergoing this cure?
"Not at the beginning.
No, not at the beginning, no.”
“It was only later in the treatment that you --you required this?
Answer “I was not responding to treatment very well.”
And then as to the two previous cases on record 117, he says, “But you did build up two other cases?”
“In some months previously, yes.
"Some months previously?"
"Yes.”
“And isn't it a fact that in not going there to Nick but in approaching this defendant you had in mind building up a case against the defendant to give the Bureau of Narcotics?"
So, that it does appear that at the time he was getting narcotics from Sherman and was going to the doctor.
He didn't have a source of supply of his own.
He was trying to get some for himself.

And that the defendant, rather than leading to his own source, saw that opportunity to get back into the narcotic business which he had previously been in 1942 and which he -- for which he had possession of narcotics or purchase of narcotics.
He'd been convicted in 1946.
And he's a man that's been dealing in narcotics or -- or addicted to narcotics for -- for 9 years.
Now, that -- that evidence to me has some persuasion in -- in whether he was a person who was again willing to get into the traffic and who was a person, who was, otherwise, an -- an innocent person.
Now, again I come back to the argument of entrapment.
That entrapment is a defense for the innocent, the people that are not engaged in crime, and not engaged in this particular advantage.
It's not a -- a defense for a fellow who is in the business.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is there any evidence that you've seen in the record?
I haven't read it all, but was there any evidence in the record that he was up at his doctor's office for any purpose except to get him to the transfer and decided to stop himself?

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: No, sir.
There's no evidence in there other than that.
As a matter of fact the only evidence that I can recall was that he told Kalchinian that he was there for the purpose of the cure.
He was trying to get a cure but at the time he was buying narcotics.
So, I --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was that in the record?

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: I don't know if there were or if you should believe him on that.
But there is no record that he was there for the purpose of trying to find someone to sell narcotics or do anything in that sense, I would say, Your Honor.
But we feel that this -- this evidence of prior offenses was admissible.
Again going to the predisposition of the defendant and his guilty mind at the time of the sales in question.
And again, the Sorrells case is important because as they -- as they point out, once he opens this door to entrapment, then the Government in such a case can bring other evidence into play.

For example, they say, that if the defendant seeks acquittal, by reason of entrapment, he cannot complain of an appropriate and searching inquiry into his own conduct and predisposition is bearing on that issue.
If in consequence he suffers a disadvantage, he has brought it upon himself by reason of the nature of the offense.
And it's about just like the fellow that puts his character in evidence like we found in the Michelson case, where they asked him, his character witnesses if they knew he'd been arrested in 1920.
And this Court held that was all right that he opened up the issue.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But for the prior conviction -- but for the prior conviction, the case would be the same it was at the first trial, would it not?

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: Your Honor, I -- I hesitate to say that because I did not see the record in the first trial but from reading the opinion of the Second Circuit in 200 F.2d, I would say that it is.

As far as I know, except for the record of the convictions and the record of the -- of Mr. Lowenberg for the price paid for the narcotics and the -- and the fact that he had previously purchased the same amount for a lesser price that is, and he testified, I think, that he got the same amount for $10 from his other places where he could purchase.
In other words, this man had been an addict.
And he bought narcotics before so that there is some evidence in there to show that Sherman was in the business for profit --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: There is no --

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: -- that there was not in the first place.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- affirmance.
The Government didn't affirmatively direct evidence to indicate the $25 was an exorbitant price.
Was there?

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: No, sir.
I did not find any evidence in the record of that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Supposing that, isn't it also fair reasoning that if it is wrong for the -- for the Government to try to induce a strong-minded, innocent person to commit a crime, when he finally succumbs to it, that it is more wrong for the Government to try to induce a poor addict who is struggling with himself and is -- is going to a doctor everyday in order to try to break himself of the habit, and can you say that -- can you say that the -- the mere fact that the man is an addict, gives the Government the -- the right to induce him to commit this crime just because he's a person who might be likely to succumb?

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: I don't think that the Government would have any such right there.
Well, I think that it's --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)
-- haven't you got that -- haven't you got that situation here, Mr. Knapp?
You've got this -- this poor fellow, both of them poor fellows, who are sitting in this -- in this doctor's office, both of them trying to break themselves of this habit.

And one of them who is connected up with the -- with the Government, Narcotic Bureau for some reason or other, whether it's money or whether it's -- it's influence or perhaps leniency on the part of the -- of the Bureau, one of them chooses to cooperate with -- with the Government in making these cases.
And he induces some poor devil who is in that office trying to break himself of the habit under a doctor's -- doctor's care.
Now, if there is such a thing as entrapment, shouldn't that be entrapment?

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: I don't think so, in this case, Your Honor, because he -- as -- as Kalchinian's testimony, as I read it, is that he, the defendant offered to sell it to him.
He tried to find who defendant -- his source of supply.
And -- and instead the defendant offered to sell it to him.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Oh --

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: As I say, there maybe --

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: -- some question on that, but that's the way I read the record.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I've read this and I don't think it'll bear that out Mr. Knapp.

The man, Kalchinian admits, I don't want to go all over this because it's pretty late, but as I read it, Kalchinian, first approached him in the office, asked him how he was doing, and then told him -- asked him if he could tell him where he could get some.

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Then told him he needed it badly.
And finally, on about the third or fourth time, this man said, well I can't introduce you to anybody, but I can get, maybe get you some.
And I'll share it with you,.
And then he went and -- he went and got them.

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: Well, that's -- that's about --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: -- as I -- as I read the testimony, Your Honor, that's about the size of it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
Well, now when you (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: If you think it over it's about the --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: -- size of it, but Kalchinian insists I didn't ask him to sell it to me.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, but that's --

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: And now I mean --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- that's a play on words, it seems to me --

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: Yes.
That maybe --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- he -- he wanted this man to go out and get for him.
That's what you -- that's the purpose of his questioning.

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: I -- I don't think so.
I think he wanted him to tell him where he could get it.
I think there's a distinction there.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, then why didn't he stay with that?
Why didn't he stay with it?
What -- what difference would he --

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You mean he wouldn't have taken it the easy way, that is, if this man could get it for him, that he would insist on wanting to go and buy it himself?

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: Oh, I don't think it made any difference to him how he got it.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: That's what I mean.

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: But as his -- his testimony is that he asked him to -- to put him in touch with a source and did not ask him to sell him the narcotics.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well that -- that (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: Now, that --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I didn't say that.

turn.speaker: james_w_knapp
turn.label: Mr. James W. Knapp
turn.text: All right, sir.
Is there any other --

turn.speaker: henry_a_lowenberg
turn.label: Mr. Henry A. Lowenberg
turn.text: Now, I'd just like to have (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, yes, you may.

turn.speaker: henry_a_lowenberg
turn.label: Mr. Henry A. Lowenberg
turn.text: -- about two or three minutes.
If the Court pleases, the direct transcript will show on page 67 that this Kalchinian was convicted in 1952.
On page 99, it'll show that he had promised to cooperate with the Government in 1951.
And that was before his sentence.
So that he was cooperating with the Government up to the time that he got a suspended sentence in 1952, which was past the dates of this alleged division of narcotics between Kalchinian and Sherman.
Now he -- as on the question as to whether he was a hired man or not, all I will say to this Court is this.
That Kalchinian (Inaudible) admitted on a witness stand.
He says, "I didn't want to go to jail, that was all there was to it.
I was ready to do anything, cooperate with the Government.
That was my purpose to save myself from going to jail."
Well, that's payment sufficient for anybody.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: henry_a_lowenberg
turn.label: Mr. Henry A. Lowenberg
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What sentence (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: henry_a_lowenberg
turn.label: Mr. Henry A. Lowenberg
turn.text: Ten years, under the statute, because prior -- two prior convictions, mandatory ten years, that's it.
Ten years for being an addict, being in a doctor's office and being induced by a fellow addict employed by the Government.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Gentlemen, we have one more case on the calendar, Number 92.
Counsel here from out of town, I wonder if they would rather hear that -- hear it on Monday afternoon or have it continued to the February calendar

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right, it's a -- a summary case.
Well, you could -- you could let us know.
You can let us know after we -- after we adjourn (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All right.
Thank you.
